pageData.title: Overview
pageData.text: In this investigation, students will learn about bacterial characteristics and the purpose and process of staining bacteria. They will then observe and interpret photographs of stained bacteria.

pageData.text: Individual bacterial cells are commonly described as <button class='glossary-text'>bacillus</button> (rod-shaped), <button class='glossary-text'>coccus</button> (spherical), and spiral. But the growth of colonies of bacteria and other microorganisms can be much more complex. Colonies are often described as being raised, smooth, flat, filamentous, irregular, circular, etc. Some bacteria are capable of forming macro-colonies that form multiple patterns.

Tal Danino is a synthetic biologist at the Synthetic Biological Systems Lab at New York City’s Columbia University. He is trying to understand what environmental conditions stimulate different growth patterns in microbial colonies. He hopes that by finding the cues that the colonies use to communicate and survive, he can use that knowledge to fight cancer<sup>1</sup>.

pageData.subTitle: Bacteria Cell Structure
pageData.text: Bacterial cells can be found in just about every environment in nature. Bacterial cells are very small, typically about 0.2 μm in diameter. Thus, to see individual cells and groups of cells, a microscope is necessary.

A bacterial cell is similar to a cell in a plant or an animal. For example, these cells all contain genetic material, cytoplasm, and a . Like a plant cell, bacterial cells get their structure from a rigid . Some bacteria have an that covers their cell wall in addition to the cell membrane found beneath the cell wall. The outermost layer of any bacterial cell is the . Composed of complex sugars and proteins, the capsule not only enhances the ability of the bacteria to cause disease but also protects the cell from engulfment by larger cells. Many bacteria have special structures, such as (for sticking to other cells and surfaces) or (for propelling the cell forward).

pageData.subTitle: Bacteria Characteristics
pageData.text: Prokaryotic bacterial cells are much smaller and simpler in structure than eukaryotic cells. Stained bacteria can be described in terms of their (shapes) and . A first step in identifying bacterial species is determining the cell morphology. Single cells can be rods , spirals or spherical . There can be slight variations in morphology to include short rods (), flexible spirals (), and slightly curved rods .

Cell arrangements can also be used to identify bacterial species. Arrangements are determined by the number of planes of division and if the cells separate after division. Cocci and bacilli commonly form multicellular associations, including attached daughter cells ( and and continued division in the same plane results in long chains ( and ). A tetrad () is formed if a second division occurs perpendicular to the first division, and a forms when a cube-shaped arrangement of cells occurs. An irregular cluster of cells () results from irregular division planes. Spirilla are rarely seen in arrangements other than single cells.

pageData.question: Which type of bacteria is rarely seen in arrangements other than single cells?

feedbackData.title: Feedback
feedbackData.text: Spirilla are rarely seen in arrangements other than single cells. Chain-like arrangements of bacteria use the prefix “strepto-”; irregular cluster arrangements of bacteria use the prefix “staphylo-”.

pageData.question: Which of the following describes bacteria with a spherical shape that divide along the same plane into long chains?

feedbackData.title: Feedback
feedbackData.text: Cocci have spherical cells. When such bacteria divide along the same plane into long chains they are known as streptococcus.

pageData.subTitle: Staining
pageData.text: Many bacterial cells are colorless, so there is little contrast to distinguish them from the surface of the microscope slide. Staining the bacterial cells adds contrast for ease of viewing. techniques help microbiologists see bacterial cells more easily with a microscope. Addition of just one type of stain is called simple staining and is used mainly to visualize, not categorize, bacterial cells. More advanced staining techniques, such as and , use multiple stains and can be used for identification and classification purposes.

Most dyes used to stain cells are molecules with a charged portion, called the , contained in a solvent (usually ethanol or water). If dissolved in a solution, the chromophores are attracted to cellular structures bearing the opposite charge and repelled by those bearing the same charge.

A negatively charged chromophore, characteristic of an , is attracted to positively charged cellular structures and repelled by negatively charged ones. Because bacterial cells typically have a negative surface charge, acidic stains are strongly repelled by them. The cell will remain clear and colorless, but the stain will adhere to the surface of the slide (see Figure 3). Examples of acidic stains include nigrosin and India ink.

pageData.altText: Figure 3: A negatively stained bacteria

pageData.text: A positively charged , characteristic of a , is attracted to negatively charged cellular structures and repelled by positively charged ones. Because bacterial cells typically have a negative surface charge, basic stains are strongly attracted to them. The stained cell will appear dark against the unstained surface of the microscope slide (see Figure 4). Examples of basic stains are methylene blue, , and .

pageData.subTitle: Simple Stain
pageData.text: Before you stain a slide for viewing, the slide must be prepared so that the bacteria remain on the slide. In general, a small amount of bacterial culture (about one inoculating loop full) is applied to the surface of a clean microscope slide in an area about the size of a nickel (Figure 4a). The (smear) is allowed to air-dry so that excess fluid evaporates (Figure 4b). Then the smear is , killing most of the bacteria and causing them to adhere to the surface of the slide (Figure 4c). The application of colored dyes to the prepared slides allows the bacteria to become visible when viewed with a microscope.

Figure 4: Bacterial smear preparation. 
A. An inoculating loop spreading bacterial culture within a nickel-sized circle of ink drawn on a glass microscope slide. 
B. A dried circle of bacterial film within a circle of ink on a glass microscope slide. 
C. A microscope slide with a circle of bacterial smear being held over a small candle flame with forceps.

pageData.text: To perform a simple <button class='glossary-text'>basic stain</button> on a bacterial smear, the stain is applied to the surface of the bacterial smear (Figure 5a). The stain is then rinsed off with water (Figure 5b) and the slide blotted dry with absorbent paper (Figure 5c). Watch this video to see this simple stain being performed.

Unlike a basic stain procedure, an <button class='glossary-text'>acidic stain</button> procedure does not use a bacterial smear. Instead, a drop of stain is placed on the edge of a clean microscope slide and a loop full of bacteria is added to the stain (Figure 6a). The stain-bacteria mixture is then spread evenly across the surface of the slide using another slide (Figure 6b). The slide is allowed to air-dry before viewing (Figure 6c).

pageData.subTitle: Gram Stain
pageData.text: Differential stains require the application of more than one stain to the bacterial cells. This technique enables microbiologists to distinguish between different groups of bacteria. Figure 7 shows an example of a differential stain where two different types of bacteria are present in the same sample.

pageData.altText: Figure 7: A differential stain distinguishes Gram-positive and Gram-negative bacteria

pageData.text: The Gram stain is the most common technique (see ). It is used to distinguish among bacteria based on the composition of the . bacteria have a large quantity of a polymer called in their cell walls. bacteria have a much smaller amount of peptidoglycan, but their cell walls are covered by an (see Figure 8).

pageData.altText: Figure 8: Differences in peptidoglycan in Gram-positive and Gram-negative bacteria
Figure 9: Steps in the Gram-staining technique

pageData.text: , the purple primary stain, is applied to the bacterial smear. It initially stains all cells purple. is then applied to act as a —a substance used to “set” a stain. Iodine causes the crystal violet to become more closely associated with .

The crystal violet is rinsed off with a <button class='glossary-text'>decolorizer</button>, usually ethyl alcohol. <button class='glossary-text'>Gram-positive</button> and <button class='glossary-text'>Gram-negative</button> cells react differently to decolorizers. Gram-positive cells remain purple because their abundant peptidoglycan holds the primary stain. Gram-negative cells lose their color because the <button class='glossary-text'>outer membrane</button> dissolves and the primary stain releases from the scant peptidoglycan layer.

<button class='glossary-text'>Safranin</button>, the red <button class='glossary-text'>counterstain</button>, is applied. The safranin adds pink or red color to the Gram-negative cells. It actually stains all the cells but is not visible against the dark purple of Gram-positive cells. The counterstain is rinsed off with water, and the slide is blotted dry and ready to view.

hintData.title: Hint
hintData.body: Before you stain a slide for viewing, in general, a bacterial smear is created on a microscope slide by heat fixing bacterial cells to it. The application of colored dyes to the prepared slide allows the bacteria to become visible when viewed with a microscope. The Gram stain is the most common differential staining technique. It is used to distinguish among bacteria based on the composition of the cell wall. Gram-positive bacteria have a large quantity of a polymer called peptidoglycan in their cell walls. Gram-negative bacteria have a much smaller amount of peptidoglycan, but their cell walls are covered by an outer membrane. Crystal violet, the purple primary stain, is applied to the bacterial smear to differentiate between these two types of bacteria. It initially stains all cells purple. Iodine is then applied to set the stain by causing the crystal violet to become more closely associated with peptidoglycan. In order to contrast the appearance of Gram-negative cells against Gram-positive cells, a red counterstain (safranin) is applied to the slide.

pageData.subTitle: Acid-fast Stain
pageData.text: The is another technique. It is used to distinguish members of the genera Mycobacterium and Nocardia from most other bacteria. The wall of acid-fast-positive bacteria are rich in mycolic acid, which gives them a waxy consistency. The Ziehl-Neelsen stain is an acid-fast stain procedure. First, the bacterial smear is treated with the primary stain . The smear and primary stain are then heated, generally with steam, to drive the purple-red stain into all the bacterial cells and turn them hot pink in color. The carbolfuchsin is rinsed off with a known as acid-alcohol, a solution of hydrochloric acid diluted with ethyl alcohol. This rinsing washes the carbolfuchsin out of acid-fast-negative cells, rendering them colorless, while acid-fast-positive cells remain pink (Figure 10a). Methylene blue is then added to the smear, without heat, as a . The counterstain is rinsed off with water, leaving acid-fast-negative cells stained blue in color (Figure 10b). Acid-fast-positive cells do not retain the blue color since the stain cannot penetrate their waxy .

B. Acid-fast-negative cells under a microscope.

pageData.subTitle: Endospore Stain
pageData.text: The stain is another technique used to distinguish endospore-forming bacteria of the genera Bacillus and Clostridium from all other bacteria. Endospores are metabolically inactive, highly resistant structures produced by certain bacteria to enable survival under harsh conditions. Under favorable conditions, endospores can germinate into metabolically active vegetative cells. In Figure 11, a single endospore (indicated by the arrow) is stained a different color from the vegetative cells around it.

pageData.altText: Figure 11: Micrograph of a number of stained rod-shaped vegetative cells and one differently stained round endospore indicated by an arrow.

pageData.text: The Schaeffer-Fulton stain procedure uses the primary stain <button class='glossary-text'>malachite green</button> to stain endospores. Like the Ziehl-Neelsen method, the smear and primary stain are heated using steam to help the cells take up the stain (Figure 12). Both vegetative cells and endospores take up the malachite green. The slide is then rinsed with water as the <button class='glossary-text'>decolorizer</button>; as the malachite green washes away, vegetative cells are colorless and the endospores are green. <button class='glossary-text'>Safranin</button> is applied as the <button class='glossary-text'>counterstain</button> and rinsed off with water. The final stained smear has red or pink vegetative cells and green endospores.

pageData.altText: Figure 12: A microscope slide covered with malachite green stain on a piece of wire screen, which is on top of a beaker of water being heated on a laboratory hot plate.

pageData.subTitle: Special Stains
pageData.text: Special stains are used to reveal particular structural features of bacterial cells. Special stains include stains and stains.Some bacteria, under the right growth conditions, form a capsule. The capsule repels most stains, so a modified form of acid staining may be used to reveal its presence. There are a number of capsule stain procedures, none of which involve heat-fixing the bacterial smear since high temperatures can cause capsules to shrink. In Anthony's capsule stain, only one stain is applied, . is used as the and to rinse off excess stain. The bacterial cells and the surface of the slide appear violet, while the capsules (indicated by the arrow in Figure 13) appear clear and colorless.

pageData.altText: Figure 13: Micrograph of several stained rod-shaped bacterial cells, each surrounded by a clear colorless halo representing a capsule. One capsule is indicated with an arrow.

pageData.text: The flagella of bacteria cells are generally not visible under a compound light microscope without . The presence or absence of flagella, as well as their , can be informative for identification and classification. Heat-fixation is avoided in most flagella staining procedures to prevent damage to the fragile flagella. In the Leifson flagella stain procedure, a bacterial smear is allowed to air-dry, but is not heat-fixed. The Leifson stain contains magenta-colored in a solution of ethyl alcohol with sodium chloride and tannic acid. After the primary stain is applied, water is used to gently rinse the stain away. A may be applied, if desired, to stain the bacterial cell bodies. Figure 14 shows the appearance of flagella on a bacterium stained with Leifson flagella stain.

pageData.altText: Figure 14: Micrograph of a large elongated bacterial cell covered with many long hair-like flagella, indicated with an arrow. The cell is surrounded by many smaller rod-shaped cells, also with flagella.

hintData.title: Hint
hintData.body: Differential stains require the application of more than one stain to the bacterial cells, allowing microbiologists to distinguish between different groups of bacteria. The Gram stain is the most common differential staining technique, differentiating bacteria by the composition of their cell walls. The Ziehl-Neelsen method of acid-fast staining is another differential staining technique used to distinguish members of the genera Mycobacterium and Nocardia from most other bacteria. These bacteria have waxy cell walls due to large amounts of mycolic acid. The Schaeffer-Fulton method of endospore staining is a third example of differential staining. This technique distinguishes endospore-forming bacteria from all other bacteria. Special stains are different from differential stains in that they reveal structural features of bacteria, such as capsules or flagella, that can be used in bacterial identification. These structures are sensitive to heat and therefore their staining methods do not involve heat fixing or heat application. Anthony’s capsule stain is a modified acidic stain procedure that stains everything except the capsule, creating clear colorless halos around each cell. The Leifson method of flagella staining increases the visibility of the very thin flagella with or without a counterstain for the bacterial cells.

data.title: Acid-fast stain
data.content: A type of differential staining technique used to distinguish members of the genera Mycobacterium and Nocardia from most other bacteria

data.title: Acidic stain
data.content: A dye characterized by a negatively-charged chromophore; when applied, bacterial cells will remain colorless but the slide background will be colored

data.title: Arrangement
data.content: The spatial organization of cells as determined by the number of planes of division (if the cells separate after division)

data.title: Bacilli/bacillus
data.content: Rod-shaped bacteria

data.title: Bacterial emulsion
data.content: A dry film of a bacterial culture fixed to a microscope slide in preparation for staining; also called a bacterial smear

data.title: Basic fuchsin
data.content: A magneta-colored stain used as the primary stain in the Leifson flagella stain procedure

data.title: Basic stain
data.content: A dye characterized by a positively-charged chromophore; when applied, bacterial cells will be stained but the slide background will be colorless

data.title: Capsule
data.content: The outermost layer of a bacterial cell

data.title: Carbolfuchsin
data.content: A red-colored stain used as the primary stain in the Ziehl-Neelsen acid-fast stain procedure

data.title: Cell membrane
data.content: Separates the intracellular components from the extracellular space and allows transport in and out of cell

data.title: Cell wall
data.content: Provides rigidity and protects the cell from its environment

data.title: Chromophore
data.content: An atom or group whose presence is responsible for the color of a compound

data.title: Cocci/coccus
data.content: Spherical bacteria

data.title: Coccobacilli
data.content: Short rod-shaped bacteria; singular, coccobacillus

data.title: Copper sulfate
data.content: A solution used as the mordant in the Anthony's capsule stain procedure

data.title: Counterstain
data.content: A stain that colors the cells not already colored by another stain

data.title: Crystal violet
data.content: A purple stain; it is the primary stain used in Gram staining

data.title: Decolorizer
data.content: In Gram staining, this substance removes the stain from Gram-negative cells without affecting the stain of Gram-positive cells

data.title: Differential staining
data.content: The process of visualizing bacteria cells by the addition of more than one dye to differentiate between multiple species

data.title: Diplobacillus
data.content: Rod-shaped bacteria arranged as pairs joined end to end

data.title: Diplococcus
data.content: Spherical bacteria arranged as joined pairs

data.title: Endospore
data.content: Metabolically inactive, highly resistant structures produced by certain bacteria to enable survival under harsh conditions

data.title: Flagella
data.content: Long thin appendages that extend beyond the cell wall and propel the cell along; singular, flagellum

data.title: Gram-negative
data.content: Bacteria that have a few layers of peptidoglycan located in the periplasmic space

data.title: Gram-positive
data.content: Bacteria that have numerous layers of peptidoglycan that lie outside the periplasmic space

data.title: Heat fixed
data.content: When the process of using heat to kill and adhere bacteria to a slide is applied

data.title: Iodine
data.content: In Gram staining, this substance sets the primary stain by helping it adhere to bacterial cell walls

data.title: Malachite green
data.content: The primary stain used in the Schaeffer-Fulton endopsore stain procedure

data.title: Mordant
data.content: A substance that fixes a dye or stain in a material when the two are combined

data.title: Morphologies
data.content: Shapes of an organism

data.title: Outer membrane
data.content: A membrane that covers the cell wall of a bacteria in addition to the cell (cytoplasmic) membrane

data.title: Peptidoglycan
data.content: A polymer that forms the cell walls of many bacteria

data.title: Pili
data.content: Hair-like appendages on the surface of many bacteria; singular, pilus

data.title: Safranin
data.content: A biological stain used as a counterstain in Gram staining

data.title: Sarcina
data.content: Spherical bacteria arranged in a cube shape

data.title: Simple staining
data.content: The process of visualizing bacteria cells by making certain structures visible under a microscope

data.title: Special staining
data.content: The process of visualizing select bacteria species

data.title: Spirilla/spirillum
data.content: Rigid, spiral-shaped bacteria

data.title: Spirochetes
data.content: Flexible, spiral-shaped bacteria

data.title: Staphylococcus
data.content: Spherical bacteria arranged in irregular clusters as they continuously divide along irregular division planes

data.title: Streptobacillus
data.content: Rod-shaped bacteria arranged in long chains as they divide continuously along the same plane

data.title: Streptococcus
data.content: Spherical bacteria arranged in long chains as they divide continuously along the same plane

data.title: Tetracoccus
data.content: Spherical bacteria arranged in a group of four cells when a second division occurs perpendicular to the first division

data.title: Vibrios
data.content: Slightly curved rod-shaped bacteria
